title: Area of a region bounded by polar curves

content.question: Let R be the region in the first quadrant that is bounded by the polar curves <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGYbGaeyypa0JaeqiUdehaaa@39C9@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacqaH4oqCcqGH9aqpcaWGRbaaaa@39C2@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>, where k is a constant, <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo><</mo> <mi>k</mi> <mo><</mo> <mfrac> <mi>π</mi> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaaIWaGaeyipaWJaam4AaiabgYda8maalaaapaqaa8qacqaHapaC a8aabaWdbiaaikdaaaaaaa@3C8F@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>, as shown in the figure above. What is the area of R in terms of k ?
